reviewText:
If you're a gamer and have never heard the name Half-Life, I'm sorry to say that you're either overly sheltered, willfully ignorant or just too young. For those of us who enjoy First-Person Shooter [FPS] games, Half-Life was just as influential to the genre as Doom or Quake (for those of you who have never heard of these titles, Wikipedia is your friend). Classics such as Halo: Combat Evolved and newer titles such as Bioshock: Infinite have been influenced by this game, and older games such as Counter-Strike were mods of Half-Life. In short, the entire FPS genre has been creatively influenced by the atmosphere and style of Half-Life.                          - FYI: Final Score is at the end -

- The Look -

Half-Life was released by Valve (the parent company of Steam) in 1998 for the PC. As such, the graphics are abysmal by modern standards. If you are a nostalgic gamer such as myself, though, the low graphics can be humorous and even add to the charm of the game at times. There are numerous texture packs available if you cannot handle such old graphics.

- The Story (Mild Spoiler Alert) -

You're a government agent/scientist who gets involved with some experiments on unknown substances. Through testing these substances, you somehow open a portal and unleash an alien horde into the testing facility. You must then find and fight your way out of the facility. Pretty simple and straightforward-sounding. Half-Life was the first-ever game to tell its story completely through scripted sequences (events triggered by certain programmable requirements) and as such has no cutscenes. This is a very nice element to the game as you retain control of your character throughout the entire game.

- The Sounds -

For some reason, Valve decided they needed to make everything sound like it was coming from the inside of an echo chamber. There is a lot of reverb on just about every noise if you are not completely outdoors. Again, this is an element where modern technology has progressed as to make this appear foolish and unappealing. Give it some time before you make any judgments, though. The effect enhances the scariness of some situations, in my opinion. If you ever play any of the other Valve games (Portal, Team Fortress 2, Portal 2, etc.), you will discover that a LOT of sounds and music in those games originated from Half-Life.

- The Movement -

You run. You run a lot. You run really fast. You have the option to walk and the option to sneak, but 98% of the time you will be running. Sometimes, especially for unfamiliar novices to the game, the speed is too much and you end up running into an alien patrol before you realize that you just passed through that hallway. You will eventually get used to it, though. Half-Life was one of the first games (if not the first; I'm not sure) to implement the jump-crouch" concept. If you jump and hold the crouch button
date: you can actually jump onto higher platforms. Instead of lowering your body
recommended: jump-crouching raises your legs and feet
hoursPlayed:
giving you more clearance to vault onto objects.

- The Combat -

If an enemy sees you
voteText: they will throw a grenade. Expect to be spammed if you are spotted. Half-Life is a quick-save/quick-load supportive game; you can choose to disregard this if you want a "purist" experience. Enemies in this game are rather easy to defeat in the beginning and get harder as the game progresses
helpfulPercent: but each new type presents its own unique traits that make it hard to kill. The weapon switching system is confusing to a modern gamer at first; it requires you to scroll (or press hot-key) and then left-click to actually arm that weapon. The left shift button
votesTotal: switches instantaneously back to the previous weapon used
votesFunny:
allowing for a much faster switch. Weapons and ammo are decently plentiful if you are conservative enough.

- The Mods and The Legacy -

Half-Life is the number one most modded game of all time. There are more mods available for this game than any other
commentsCount: followed by Morrowind and Quake. The mods have spawned entire new game series
column16: as in the case of Counter-Strike and Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. Half-Life also holds the trophy for another gaming phenomenon: most-played for speedruns. If you are unfamiliar with a speedrun
column17:
the gist is that you attempt to start and finish the game as fast as possible.

- The Downsides -

Half-Life is an ancient piece of software by today's standards. With the advent of 2015
column18: this game is now 17 years old (nearly old enough to purchase cigarettes!). Its age shows in many things. Several furniture items are completely cubic or square and have no roundness. Cockroaches are diamond-shaped. There are only three different models used for the human enemies and three for the friendly scientists. Each alien type has only one model/skin. The NPCs and enemies can get very repetitive at times
column19: as such. Other than this
column20:
there aren't very many bad points to Half-Life. Its continued success and popularity speak for its quality and innovation.

- The Conclusion -

Half-Life is a classic in many gamers' opinions. I am of the same mindset. I completely recommend this game
column22: as a fun experience that will provide a decent challenge.\n\nFinal Score: 10/10"

reviewText:
I finally got the chance to buy & play this amazing game in the steam exploration sale so I'll try my best to explain this game in my point of view.

Oh boy where to start well for starters this game is one of the main reasons Valve is highly respected & over 4 million gamers are still waiting for Half Life 3 including me, Gordon Freeman is a badass scientist that can fight off the military & a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of aliens, lots of weapons to choose from, the atmosphere is pretty spot on with the suspense of fighting off soldiers or just overall creepiness in Xen (the alien world), I could tell the game has had a lot of love because the game works fine on any PC & there's so many great things I can say about this game but I don't want to make an entire list of everything. G-man a.k.a Government Man (The slang is right here http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G-Man_%28slang%29 if you don't know what it means) interests me because of his mysterious behaviour & everyone still wants to know if he fights for good or evil but some things in life can't be answered but I don't know if we could all handle the truth.... if you really want more questions added I would suggest this video it gives out some good theories on G-Man & many others you can watch on youtube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_HmxQi09brI

The game has few minor bugs but the game still holds out as one of the grandfathers of the FPS genre & still popular for a 16 year old game so my final verdict is to get this game. Don't forget keep some head crabs as souvenirs on your grand adventures in Black Mesa, Freeman's grandkids might want it for their school project or for bragging rights on how cool their grandpa was back in his scientific glory. (If you feel like I missed something feel free to leave feedback)

reviewText: Half-Life is a science fiction first-person shooter video game developed by Valve Corporation, the company's first game product and the first in the Half-Life series. Released in 1998 by Sierra Studios , in Half-Life, you assume the role of Dr. Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist who must fight his way out of a secret underground research facility whose research and experiments into teleportation technology have gone disastrously wrong. Half-Life is a first-person shooter that requires the player to perform combat tasks and puzzle solving to advance through the game. Compared to most first-person shooters of the time, which relied on cut-scene intermissions to detail their plotlines, Half-Life‍ '​s story is told entirely by means of scripted sequences, keeping you in control of the first-person viewpoint. In line with this, the game has no cut-scenes, and you rarely loses the ability to control Gordon, who never speaks and is never actually seen in the game; the player sees through his eyes" for the entire length of the game. It also has multiplayer and because this is not the original version

reviewText:
I shall direct this review for the people that haven't played or heard of this game-

Yes, this is that one.  The game that all others were measured against for a long, long time.

In a world where FPS games compelled you to shoot anything that moved in fantastical arenas with weapons that floated and rotated in the air, Half-Life came along and quietly stated...

..I want to tell a story"

It doesn't thrust you into the shoes of a hardcore soldier or special forces operative
date:
you start your day with a leisurely train ride.  As a scientist.  Going to work.  Just like any other day...

The level design was phenominal and vaired.  The combat was robust and fun.

I'll stop there.

The bottom line is...this game costs almost nothing and will run on almost anything out there today.  Your excuses are limited to why you wouldn't try your hand at this classic.

Modern gamers might have to put on rose covered glasses and step back a few years to fully appreciate it when it was cutting edge and new...but names like Blast Pit
hoursPlayed: and Xen still mentioned by some with warm feelings and happy memories even to this day.  And if you can't stomach the GoldSource engine...download Black Mesa.\n\nThis is one that I wish I could experience again for the first time."

reviewText:
Half-Life - a word used for stating the time it takes for a nuclear substance to reach half its original amount, but also - a great game!

Released for Windows computers originally in November 19th, 1998, it came to redefine the era of modern first-person shooters. With a simple change in concept compared to other big games of the time, namely the fact that you never leave the players field of vision, the focus was always on the player, even during special events in the storyline. And the story - what a story it was and still is!

In the game, you play as Gordon Freeman, an M.I.T graduate in Theoretical Physics, who is called to the Black Mesa Complex as a Research Associate for a large-scale experiment involving alien artifacts. Already from the get-go, you may pass your time by speaking to, or just listen to the conversations between scientists and security guards. You may interact with doors, buttons, microwaves, soda machines - I mean, what more can anyone ask for, right?

I am not going to spoil the story for anyone interested in playing the game themselves (go play it already, if you haven't!), but I can say that the ability to interact with the surrounding world is something that the player learns to appreciate throughout the game. Because of this ability, there are often several ways to complete a certain task (moving boxes, blowing things up, pressing a switch so that you don't get caught by an electrified wire etc.). This is something that  works very well with the game's overall story and design.

As the game progresses, Gordon comes face to face with stronger and stronger enemies who use different tactics to bring him down. Without ever uttering a word, Gordon swings his Crowbar (or perhaps his trusted shotgun) and plows them through, persevering through yet another life-threatening situation. It is just how badass he is (you are).

Most of the times though, there is a lot of button-pushing in this game. Luckily, this is where the M.I.T-graduation comes in handy - for who could ever push a button the way M.I.T graduates can? Jokes aside though, he is darn fast at climbing ladders (while holding his crowbar with two hands - how does he do it?)!

Personally, I really enjoy this game through and through. The Source engine allows for some slick movement and fast-paced gaming. If you take your time to listen to random scientists, you may or may not be surprised to hear that many of them are just as human as you and me. This is something that adds to the game and integrates the player further into the story, in my opinion. The story is great and the enemies have very advanced A.I for the time (1998, remember - that's 16 years ago!). I would recommend this game for every and any player who has ever played FPS-games, but even more so to any Quake, Doom or Unreal Tournament fans out there. So come on, give it a spin - it'll be worth it!

reviewText: There is not much to say about this old game that hasn't been said really. Many people have played Half-Life 2 and the episodes, but sometimes there are those few who haven't really tried out the original Half-Life, along with it's expansions Blue Shift and Opposing Force. I also never played Half-Life, so I decided to try it out. Many mechanics are simialr to its sequel with many of the same guns, along with some other ones unique to this game. This game is an amazing experience from the begining to the end, despite the not as strong end levels, but still, it's a great shooter with great mechanics and gunplay, along with great level desgin not seen as much now in today's corridor shooters. The story is presented through the eyes of the silent Gordon Freeman the entire time, and despite the games old graphics, still makes the game incredibly immersive, even more so than many games today on the market. The expansions are also worth your time and are neccessary to purchase, and you can get a discount by buying the Half Life 1 Anthology. The only reason you would not play this is the simplistic graphics, but with people playing games like Minecraft, along with the greatness of this historic masterpiece, this is a must buy, and you should definitely be played BEFORE PLAYING HALF-LIFE 2 AND THE EPISODES. Anyway, I was just bored and had some time on my hands. So just remember, NEVER be late for work.

reviewText:
Half-Life is one my favorite games.

I was a freshman in High School in the fall of 1999 when my group of friends got into it. I still remember when my good friend Brandon and I started up the game for the first time and we were just amazed at the opening scene. It's the most mundane scripted piece but you have to understand that, in that time period, this kind of real immersive gameplay simply didn't exist. It was revolutionary.

This set the tone for the rest of the game. The scripted events, the continuous gameplay, the lack of loading screens, the beautifully designed levels, the complex storyline that was revealed gradually not through expository cut scenes, but, through observation; this was new and it was amazing.

The multiplayer scene of Half-Life was equally new and exciting. Half-Life was hardly the birthplace of online First Person Shooter deathmatch; that belongs to Doom and its successor Quake. But that community migrated to Half-Life and I was aware of their presence and respected their experience, hardly realizing that I myself was experiencing a change in gaming.

You can't talk about Half-Life multiplayer without talking about the mods. 'Science and Industry', 'Action Half-Life', 'Day of Defeat', 'Pirates, Vikings and Knights' and, of course, 'Counter-Strike', a series which has gone on to become the biggest name in online FPS gaming. These ever evolving player made modifications were apart of a thriving creative community that came together to celebrate Half-Life's GoldSrc engine and the possibilities it presented for user-created content. It was a wonderful time.

Half-Life's glory has since been eclipsed by its successor, Half-Life 2, which PC Gamer named as the greatest game of all time on their 2015 annual list. The original Half-Life, however, still represents a special time period for gaming, both in my group of friends and in the wider world of PC gaming.

Removing myself for just a moment from the pangs of nostalgia, is Half-Life still a game I'd recommend? The answer is an unequivocal yes. It's still beautiful, fun, innovative, atmospheric and has a heck of a story. It's video game history. Give it a go.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of my All time favorite games. It had everything i desire from a game in 1998. It is impressive.

For today's standards, it has aged graphics, but still plays extremely well, and is really entertaining. Story is told mostly via dialogue from other characters, as the main character is mute, well at least in the game(s). I doubt he is really mute if he got a job like that.

You shoot your way through aliens, and soldiers which try to kill everything inside the Black Mesa Facility. Levels are diverse, game is long enough for single player campaign. I love it.

Apart from SP, game has multiplayer modes, which probably isn't that much populated. To compensate that, there are tons of mods for HL1. New gamemodes for MP, new maps, whole new single player games. Just google some of the best mods, and you have so many that you won't know which to play.

Classic, you should play this if you have not already. If you have, play it again!
If you are turned off by the looks of the game( Which I don't think should be a problem, it's older game)
Look up Black Mesa on steam. It's HL2 Mod, which remade HL1 into HL2's engine, which better visuals and other tweaks.  Black Mesa is still missing the games ending at the moment( Early 2016), but otherwise it's solid example of good remaster.

reviewText:
HALF-LIFE. WRITTEN REVIEW NOT COMPLETE

quote. Scientist: [playing with tie] Why do we all have to wear these ridiculous ties?.

Developed by Valve and released in 1998

Pros and Cons

pros. Everything
cons. Nothing

STORYLINE
A mysterious Alien Artifact has been recovered and brought to a top-secret research facility in the Black Mesa. When newcomer Dr. Gordon Freeman is assigned to physically test the artifact, things go very wrong when the artifact opens a destructive and unstable portal to Xen, a planet in a different dimension. Gordon blacks out, and awakes in a now crippled and ruined research facility. When Freeman and the survivors of this ordeal discover the portal has allowed its inhabitants-deadly alien creatures-to enter the facility, they realise that they must call the government for help. The government, however, already has plans to contain this incident by silencing the witnesses.

Half life's story is a very diverse and confusing one, but is still executed brilliantly. since Half Life does not rely on cut scenes, there are moments when subtle important plot references are hinted towards key features of the story, but these references can be left unnoticed especially on a first play-through. This really depends on the player and their play style if you are to notice these references. Therefore this game mechanic should not be seen as a flaw rather as an attempt to try something new that valve knew very well wouldn’t mix with everyone.

GAMEPLAY
Half life is the most influential First Person Game Ever Made. This is best exemplified through its game play mechanics. Let me explain.

Growing up as a young grommet the only fps game I was familiar with was DOOM. At the time DOOM was piratically seen as the best pc game of all time. All fps games two follow copied the DOOM formula, all except half life. You see Doom had

.NO Apparent storyline
.NO Interesting characters
.NO Absorbing atmosphere [It felt very arcade like]
.And no real apparent goal

The game was really a stress reviler where you just shoot s.hit and blow c.unts up. Not saying DOOM is a bad game. DOOM is one of my favourite games its just that Half life beat DOOM at the fps formula in all ways by Half Life having

.A fantastic and engaging story.
.A scary immersive atmosphere.
.A roster of witty and interesting characters.
.A simplified moving mechanic
.A mechanic where you could look up and down.{ thank F.UCK for that }
.A Mixture of action and Puzzles
.And a game with an apparent goal from the very start.

You see Half Life wasn’t one of those games where you would just shoot s.hit and blows c.unts up. Half Life was the first real fps game to feel like a immersive gaming experience. Therefore we have half life to thank for saving and changing what was commonly thought of as the First Person Shooter Genre.

PACING
Half Life Pacing is Executed very well. The game has the whole survival horror game feel to it and the game really exemplifies this through a sense of dread. At the start of the game it is apparent that you need to escape the black mesa facility but only an hour down the track you start to lose recognition of that thought and just have the mindset of surviving, and that is why this games pacing is so good. You never quite feel like you have an objective to do rather you just feel you have to survive. and coupling this with the fine selection of jump-scares and mind blowing scripted events it truly holds up.

LEVEL DESIGN
Valve has a name for level design in their games. Its hard to describe on paper but no gaming developer team does it like valve, you just have to see it for yourself, I mean talk about attention to detail. Before Half Life level design in fps video games were very simplistic and felt like an arcade experience. Half Life's level design was truly ahead of its time. Structures would collapse, you could interact with all most everything from the environment, and the game used a clever use of scripted events through the level design. It is very hard to explain on paper but you can tell a lot of work was put into this category of game design for half life.

SOUNDTRACK
Half-Life soundtrack consists of a techno and ambience like tracks. One of Half Life's key elements two its atmosphere is said soundtrack. Half Life's soundtrack always seems to change conveniently creating a completely different mood and atmosphere to the last segment of the game. The use of ambience like tracks for the more creepy, mysterious moments through out the game coupled with the techno prodigy like tracks for the scripted action moments through out the game really create an experience like no other. Not two mention the end credits theme witch really feels rewarding and catchy... here is a link to the end credits theme soundtrack https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bXpGM6NgrZ8

reviewText:
At the Black Mesa Research Facility, scientists dive into the unknown only to find ruin and death as the cost of their discovery, opening a portal to an alien world. One scientist, the crowbar-wielding Dr. Gordon Freeman must set out on a journey through the facility to close the portal and protect the people who are still alive.

As outdated as it might be in 2015, Half-Life has entertained players across the world with it's story, and its legacy would go on to produce mods, spin-offs and a sequel (but STILL no Half-Life 3).

Pros:
+Captivating storyline
+Unique puzzles
+Wide variety of weaponry
+Great soundtrack
+Modding compatiablity

Cons:
-Everything about it is outdated (visuals, voice acting, textures, etc.) and may turn off players looking for a more modern game
-More glitchy than one might expect

reviewText:
Half-Life is an amazing FPS experience released almost 20 years ago and that still hold strong today. The graphics will look dated to some, and the sound can be unbearable to others, but the story and the way the environment is layed out makes you realize how much work went into this (It must have been amazing to play this in 1998).

The game is the classic shooter experience where you grind through waves of enemies, sometimes fighting a boss or one of the huge mobs that appear from time to time. The game is very hard, even at the lower difficulties (much harder than HL2) and is a good challenge for fans of old-school FPS classics such as Doom and Quake.

I recommend any game from the Half-Life series because of the effort that went into making these games. If you really can't stand the graphics and sound, you can always check out Black Mesa, a remake of HL1 (it isn't completely done yet iirc).

reviewText:
Maybe Black Mesa... or how Gordon Freeman changed the world - a must-have, if you're not a graphic next-gen purist.

During an experiment gone wrong, where you're the one that pushed the crystal into the analyzer, you're the only hope of the survivors to reach the search and rescue team, because of your combinaison. However, you'll have to survive from the attacks of your coworkers transformed in zombies and creatures coming from another world. And unfortunately for you, your only weapon is a crowbar. And you're just a scientist employed by Black Mesa...

That's Half-Life for you. A scientist relying on a crowbar first before becoming an expert in weapons. The story is perhaps basic and with some twists but noneless, the universe build around Half-Life has expanded a lot.

However, if Half-Life is a FPS, which means weapons to shoot any enemies, that you can carry thanks to your wonderful combinaison, you can find some puzzles throughout the game, mainly because of the need to wander around a destroyed facility.

What's fascinating in Half-Life isn't probably the gameplay in itself. I mean, everything seems very basic. But if it wasn't for it, you wouldn't have mods like Counter-Strike around. I don't know why I was fascinated by Half-Life. I mean, it's not like jumping was new or that weapons were innovative... maybe the iconic crowbar has to do something with. Or maybe it's just that a plot, perhaps basic but very effective, the mysterious G-Man following you around and disappearing easily or that the fact it's someone that wasn't trained to become the hero of the world... or maybe the ending. I don't know but I just know that when I played it, I was fascinated.

I was fascinated by the fact that you can find survivors around that can help you, guards or scientists. Or the fact that some of them meet a tragic fate under your eyes. I was fascinated by the change of the objectives: from reaching the surface, you're now the only hope to end an invasion and the wiping of any survivor by the soldiers.

I don't remember any problem with the gameplay apart the treacherous ladders. Climbing them isn't hard. However, when you needed to step out of them OR going down, it was a challenge. And the famous jumping with the crates where you were sliding...

Half-Life has the graphics from 1998 and it was very good ones. Even now, I could still enjoy them. I don't say that it's detailed. But you can see some interesting details. And Xen, the other world, despite being a challenge, is very beautiful.

Besides, the soundtrack is also great. It's only heard during some important moments. But the music is powerful.

Half-Life is a classic to have. Gordon Freeman is a character that you can't forget.

reviewText: É um ótimo FPS com uma ambientação e uma história bem interessantes. Você está no controle de Gordon Freeman, um físico que trabalha na Black Mesa Research Facility, onde são feitos diversos tipos de pesquisas. Freeman participa de um experimento que dá errado, criando um efeito cascata que ocasiona a invasão de aliens no local. Assim, ele precisa entender como reverter o incidente. O jogo tem diversos tipos de armas e de inimigos que, sem querer dar muito spoiler, não se limitam a extra-terrestres. A ação é o foco, mas não quer dizer que você não terá que parar e pensar um pouco em alguns momentos para resolver situações pontuais a fim de poder progredir. Uma facilidade que o jogo tem é poder salvá-lo a qualquer momento. Hoje em dia os gráficos não são tão atrativos, mas para a época de lançamento com certeza surpreenderam. A trilha sonora é quase inexistente, servindo para marcar apenas alguns momentos. Há mais de um final possível e um deles vai desenvolver os eventos em Half-Life 2. Então, se você tem interesse em shooters clássicos, não deixe de conferir Half-Life e de entender os detalhes de sua trama. E lembrando que existem mais duas histórias que se passam nas mesmas ocasiões, com personagens diferentes, em Half-Life Opposing Force e Half-Life Blue Shift.

reviewText:
Half-Life does something no game has ever done before. It become popular among people that never even played it.

Counter-Strike. Day of Defeat. Team Fortress. The Specialists. Natural Selection. I could go on listing the great mods, and games, that has come about as a result of Half-Life. It is not just a single game, when you buy Half-Life you are buying literally hundreds of games.

Half-Life is an impressive game in it's own right too, the graphics were amazing for the time and the gameplay and story were great but that all pales in comparison to what this game has done for the world of gaming in general.

This is what made modding popular. This is why games today have mod support and why mods sometimes become games.

The next time you play a game with mods, with plugins, with graphical enhancement, with fan made maps, with total conversions. The next time you play a game that used to be mod. Say thanks to Half-Life.

Half-Life didn't event modding. It made it popular.

reviewText:
You are Gordon Freeman. A scientist who works for the Black Mesa facility. And an experiment you took part in has gone completely awry, unleashing an extraterestrial invasion, and now all hell has broken loose in Black Mesa. Your main goal is to survive and to stop the invasion, using the help of surviving Black Mesa employees, whatever you can get your hands on and your own bare wits.

Even if it is over a decade old, Half Life has aged very, very well. In fact it seems to do some things better than most Modern shooters - you can hold a heck of a lot of weapons for example, a great feature that barely has any presence in shooters nowadays. The gunplay is intense but fair, and you have a huge multitude of weapons to utilise - and they are all great and feel powerful. Enemy types are plentiful, varied and can get pretty darn tough as the game progresses. The enemy AI itself is intelligent and fierce - especially the soldiers who know how to flank well and work together. There are friendly NPC's as well, which are actually helpful: Security guards can help deliver covering fire and scientists can unlock doors and heal you if you are low on health. The game also takes good advantage of the environmental elements around it, technically making almost everything a threat or obstacle - some bridges can be destroyed which may require you to find another way around it, wet floors are obviously slippy so you need to be careful not to slide into an elevator shaft - Did I also mention that elevators in this game are barely ever safe? All of these great uses of particular stage elements called for some fantastically designed levels and puzzles that require a skilled gamer to complete.

Graphically, I will admit the game does look a bit blocky by today's standards and the character animations are pretty wooden, but each level within Half Life looks worlds apart from one another, especially the last part of the game, trust me, it's amazing, that's all I'm saying about it, I'm not gonna spoil it. The character and enemy designs themselves, most notably the aliens, are really creative, unique and varied. The real time cutscenes were cutting edge back in the day and even though the choppy and kinda unexistant character animations during these cutscenes are now dated in a sense, the fact that they are REAL TIME just makes them very immersive and makes you feel part of a great story.

When it comes to audio, the soundeffects are great and fits Half Life's sci-fi tone, and the guns are LOUD. The music tracks, although few and far between, are fantastic and give off great atmosphere. The voiceacting is also great, even if the recordings are a bit grainy.

If there was anything I thought that did detract from the overall quality from the game, is the fact that sometimes the player can get glitched in certain parts of the environment, so they can't move, therefore they would need to restart from the last save... but then again this barely ever happens.

Tl;dr Half Life is a groundbreaking FPS that has stood the test of time and I still consider it as one of the best shooters ever made, if not the best. An immersive, action packed, incredibly varied FPS that makes you feel like an action hero. Highly recommended to anyone who has at least an interest in videogames.

reviewText:
Half-Life
What is there to say about this game? Well actually, alot. This game is absolutely fantastic. Personally, I prefer it over 2. Anyways, with my opinion out of the way, I'm going to elaborate about why this game is so  great.
The story starts with you, Gordon Freeman. The 27 year old scientist with a degree in Theoretical Physics. Not much to say about that.
Your workplace, Black Mesa, gets attacked by various aliens and the marines when an transfer goes wrong.
The thing about this game is that theres a huge element of surprise. You'll find out what I mean when you play the game.
Yea.
Plot twists, man.
Anyways, the gameplay. That makes the whole game.
The gameplay is absolutely fantastic for an FPS. However, this isn't just any FPS with some macho guy ripping monster heads off because it's fun (I'm looking at you, Duke Nukem.)
This is, what I would call an action-adventure FPS. This game really set the standard for the genre.
There's a fair assortment of weapons. Speaking of weapons, you're going to need ammo. Alot of it.
That's not necessarily a bad thing - it's everywhere. Or atleast, it's not very hard to find ammo.
The other thing with this game is that, you, the player needs to be very patient. This game has backtracking. Alot of it.
Next thing, the graphics. The graphics aged fairly well, in my opinion. Sure, some of the models might look wonky, but it can be easily fixed with a few HD mods.
There is music in this game. Although, they only really play during intense parts, it's still quite well composed.
If you look past the backtracking and constant dying, you'll love this game. Trust me.
It's absolutely fantastic, and really set the standards for the FPS genre after 1998.
That's not all I have to say about Half-Life, but if I did, you and I would be here all day.

Final Verdict:
9.5/10
An absolute fantabulous masterpiece

Half life I know that graphics aren't best in this game, but it was made in 1998. This is one of best FPS games. And yeah did I mentioned that this won 50 awards? So buy, play it.

Story:
You are gordon Freeman. An theoretical physic that comes to Black Mesa research facility. You are coming to experiment (Anti-Mass Spectrometer). But resonance cascade will happen. So a lot of xen aliens start teleport from Xen to Earth. And Xen aliens aren't only one that want to kill you. Army is also sent to Black Mesa to kill any survivors of resonance cascade. Can you save the Earth? You need to kill a monster called Nihilanth.

reviewText:
Despite its age, Half-Life is still one of the greatest examples of organic storytelling in video games. Valve’s debut title succeeds where most modern games fail—in telling a story without interrupting the game’s pacing or forcing its narrative down the player’s throat.

In fact, the only time Half-Life interrupts it’s frenetic pace is to spoon feed you simplistic puzzles designed to showcase Valve’s fancy 'GoldSrc' engine, and while I’m sure it all looked fantastic back in 1998, it’s lost its relevance, and the frequent interruptions to the game are totally arbitrary now that we’ve seen things like physics engines become commonplace.

Despite technological shortcomings, the way Half-Life tells a story is better than any that came before it and most that came after it. It’s subtle and understated, favouring brief snippets of dialogue between a pair of marines or a brief set piece of a scientist being dragged into an air duct over lengthy cutscenes of exploding helicopters. It gives an air of realism contrary to the game’s sci-fi setting and sometimes over-the-top tone, and it’s a real testament to the value of organic exposition that such evocative atmospheres can be created through such subtle methods.

Surprisingly, Half-Life doesn’t let itself be carried by its storytelling. The narrative is built around solid core gameplay that boasts the tactical complexity of a more modern title on top of the large array of weapons reminiscent of older shooters. As I’ve previously mentioned, the enemy AI is subpar by today’s standards, but it’s really the level design that makes the combat stand out. The environments are varied and engaging in such a way that retains atmospheric consistency while providing some excellent combat scenarios.

Half-Life will always be a classic, and despite some janky behaviour that’s become more evident as its aged, it’s a fantastic shooter—easily one of the best to date.

reviewText:
Half-Life is my old love so I found this review kind of hard to put together, since I had to put aside my nostalgia and deliberate precisely on what makes Half-Life an excellent game, but here goes my best.

Half-Life is seemingly a classic FPS however back when It was released it was anything BUT, Half-Life was a frigging revolutionary game that defied FPS standards while still preserving what makes FPS fun and good. And Half-Life IS fun, Its got a wide and diverse range of weapons and enemies (as well as some cool bosses) and some brilliant AI that still impresses me today.

But what really makes Half-Life a really stand out game is what it does that is different. Rather then going the way of a metal gear solid game valve opted for a really interesting minimal storytelling approach in which everything is witnessed through the gameplay, there are no cutscenes of any kind. The less is more approach works and instead of long pieces of poorly written dialogue the game lets you observe first hand the chaos and destruction in the aftermath of the Black Mesa Incident. It works and the atmosphere feels like the aftermath of some kind of horrible and ongoing disaster like a huricane or a Nuclear blast In which you must fight for your life throughout the game to escape.

Rather than explain everything to you Half-Life will show you a lot of things or occasionaly say things that may confuse you. This is because you are just one man and its impossible for you to comprehend the big picture, you are small and insignificant in this grand scheme going on and while you get vague hints throughout the game as to this bigger picture the game leaves you guessing which gives the game a large sense of a forboding and sinister mystery .

This game is built on atmosphere and while the graphics have aged a lot, it is still a breath taking experiance to witness the disaster and destruction of Black Mesa. The sounds and music are top notch and aid with this of course.

If you are one of the few people who has not played Half-Life yet I really suggest that you get around to it, you wont just have fun but I think It will probably influence your opinion on how Video Game stories and atmosphere should be handled in relation to gameplay.

reviewText:
This game was released in 8th November 1998 and it's still one of the best games I've ever played. I only finished the game today and I loved it, one of the best FPS I've ever played.

You're a physicist, Gordan Freeman who goes into work late one day at the Black Mesa Research Facility.
You were meant to help with some sort of experiment so you go there and it all goes wrong, there is an explosion and you're transorted to another world and back, you wake up and some sort of alien creatures are teleporting into Black Mesa.
You need to help because every other sciencetest in this place is scared of everything and the Military has been sent in to silence the people working here so no one finds out what happened.

So you pick up every weapon you can find, a crowbar, guard's pistols, millitary machine guns, alien weapons and more.
With a goal to get yourself and others out of here, you're Gordan Freeman and will kill anything in your way.

One of the best FPS out today, enemies are varied from zombies, big aliens, zapping aliens and military soldiers, you keep killing and keep progessing.
The graphics are outdated but the game has a HD option on by default.
I give this a 10/10, you definately have to get this game.

reviewText: I honestly don't know why you're reading a review for Half-Life instead of buying it and all the other HL games, but anyway, since there are so many reviews already explaining why it's good, I'm just not gonna do that. Instead I'll just write the story of why I bought it, or mainly how I got into Steam\n\nWay back in 2012 when I was first introduced to the internet and memes, I had seen many Half Life 3 memes and I was curious as to why it was so popular, but I never bothered to research it and just went along with it. Eventually, in 2013, I created a Steam account (or maybe it was in late 2012) because of people talking about TF2 and I wanted to see what made it so great, so I downloaded TF2 and I didn't really understand how to play or what I was doing then I lost my login credentials to my Steam account and created 2 more before I finally got to this one. I didn't use Steam much at the time other than to play TF2 and I got my friends involved, too. After a while I went outside my TF2 bubble and started browsing games during a Christmas sale and bought 2 games that got a lot of attention on the internet as well, Fallout 3 and Skyrim. I played them almost 24/7 and then summer came and the 2014 summer sale started, but I had to miss out because I spent 2/3 of the summer away from home. When I came home I got back on Steam and then in August school started up, but that didn't stop me from browsing Steam and building a wishlist (I rarely got money at the time) and I found half-Life and all the other Half-Life games so I wishlisted them all. As time passed, my library grew, my wishlist shrunk, but the Half-Life games always stayed. Then, sometime in March I bought a $20 Steam wallet card and used it to buy a $10 game off my wishlist and I saved the rest for when I had more money to get a more expensive game. Then next week Lego games went on sale and I added another $5 to my account so I had $15, enough to get the Lego Batman trilogy (or at least one of the 2 I didn't own) but then I realized I could get the complete HL 1 anthology for $15 so I bought it, and played Half-Life then fell in love with the series

reviewText: Don't let the old graphics or old date fool you...this is hands down one of the best games ever made, sparking not only the hugely succesfful Half-Life series but also the Portal series. reviewText:
The game that brought one of the modern monoliths of gaming to where it is, Half-Life is a Thoroughly enjoyable romp through the Black Mesa Research Facility, a Underground scientific haven (albiet lacking in OSHA compliance)  turned to a subterranean deathtrap after a teleportation experiment gone awry.

The GoldSrc Engine -- the game engine Half-Life runs on, and forerunner to the more modern Source engine -- still provides fresh experiences more than a decade after release through a healthy modding community, with such gems as 'Afraid of Monsters', 'Sven Co-Op', 'They Hunger', and dozens of other great mods running on the beloved Quakeworld derivative.

This game is worth the low amount Valve asks for it - Go ahead, take the plunge!

reviewText:
Half Life, the game that is regarded by many to be a perfect FPS. This is especially true for the time it was made.

From the puzzles which are challenging, but not too challenging (Thanks to Valve and their excellent placement of lights and other objects that subtly cue you in) it feels really rewarding when you advance onwards.

You should expect to die many times, as you can be swarmed by multitudes of enemies if you don't start backpedelling around corners.  Oh, and a crowbar.

A major issue with the game is the sound system. Such as in the opening sequence when you're on the rail system. The slightest twitch and you can't hear what the announcer is saying, even though you are in the same position.

However, this can be overlooked because there is not a lot of Dialouge and you're mainly whacking stuff with a crowbar.

This is an amazing FPS that has actually held up quite well in terms of gameplay since it was released. The graphics may seem clunky now, but the gameplay is good.

reviewText:
around the time this game was released there were two types of video game story types. There was The Doom style, you know that stuff you mistake for credits in between blowing ♥♥♥♥ up.

There was MGS, which felt the need to beat you with exposition until you began to feel like you were a Horse. who was dying.

But narrative, true narrative, is not blowing ♥♥♥♥ up or exposition. It is what half life does. Storytelling through gameplay. It is not a simple shooting gallery, nor is it a movie where you have to do ♥♥♥♥ to get past the commercials. It is a game where gameplay and story are inseperable. Half-Life would be dull as a film. And what would it be without the G-Man? I had never played this game before, but I had heard of it. everyone has. It is considered the best of 90's PC gaming(well, it and Deus Ex.) It nails gameplay and storytelling. the tale is compelling, with action, suspense, and a hidden element of mystery.

reviewText:
Half-Life I was a game I'd heard a lot about, but I had neer played anything like it (the closest was probably 007: Goldeneye, so I wasn't quite certain of what I was getting into at first, but the Half-Life collection was on sale for only some $15, so I figured I'd take a risk.
And I'm so glad I did.  I decided, on a whim, to play it on its hardest difficulty, and I recommend you do the same, because it's just hard enough to make you be really careful, but not so hard to bring you to throw your controller across the room.
I'll address my thoughts on Half-Life I in the tradition of YouTube reviewer The Completionist:

Story 9/10
A la Zelda I, story takes a backseat in Half Life I, and I personally really like that.  There IS a story, but unlike in so many triple-A titles, it doesn't demand so much attention that the rest is neglected.  The story that exists can basically be summed up like this:
You are Gordon Freeman, a scientist with special training in the use of a power-augmenting suit, working in a top-secret facility known as Black Mesa.  After an experiment goes horribly wrong, alien creatures with no greater purpose than to kill and infect humans begin appearing around the facility, and you, as one of the only able-bodied people alive, must fight your way out of the death trap that Black Mesa has become.  But along the way, you notice a mysterious man watching your every move...
And that's it.  Most of the developments throughout the game are finding out one teensy little detail about Black Mesa's past through a stray word in normal dialogue or through coming across the aforementioned mysterious figure who watches you throughout the game.
I love it.  Having the story be so simple lets the gameplay and puzzles take a much larger role in my mind.  Instead of thinking to myself, I have to get past this puzzle so that I can know what happened to Jim
date: I'm thinking hmm...if I only have 27 health and I need to get past the lightning-throwing alien with only two bullets in my revolver
recommended: how quick will I need to fire?  And how close should I get?  Are there more enemies around him?  Maybe I could sneak past him and find a stock of ammo..." and so on.  The game prompts the player to think so much
hoursPlayed: in part because you're playing it not for the story but for the puzzles.\nThat is

it would be absolutely perfect.

No, this game invovles a lot of the thinking involved in Portal (although on a much smaller scale)--there's no objective dot like in Call of Duty. Definitely a must buy. And the multiplayer, however cheesy it may seem, is simply incredible. I never knew how accurate hip-firing could be...(Buy it and you'll see what I mean).

reviewText: Came out roughly sixteen years ago now. Revolutionized the FPS genre and how it handles story telling. Is it still worth playing? ♥♥♥♥ yes it is. The guns are loud, powerful and satisfying, the enemies are fun to fight, have decent AI and look really cool, the story is somewhat minimal but handled in a way that communicates sufficient information to the player and simultaneously doesn't interrupt the gameplay too much which lets the game keep a very fast pace and has a slight air of mysterious freakiness about it, and the level design is solid aside from some first-person platforming and most of Xen. Might be worth waiting for Black Mesa to be finished, but Half-Life 1 is still a pretty fun, excellently designed and tight game on it's own.

reviewText:
NOTE: This review is only for the single-player campaign.

In 1998, a first-person shooter called Half-Life was released by a virtually unknown startup company called Valve. It
shattered sales records, shot to the top of the review charts,won over 50 Game of the Year awards, and redefined the FPS genre. Yet, how does it hold up today?


Graphics: Half-Life's graphics, while stunning back in 1998, have aged very poorly. Textures are blurry, and character models are blocky (even with the HD Texture pack from 2001.) The lighting has aged somewhat better than the rest of the game although it is still dated. Black Mesa itself is rather boring to look at, as it is mostly gray corridors and vent shafts which is a shame because that is where the majority of the game takes place. The desert outside and the levels set on Xen are far more interesting in design though. For me though, graphics are the last thing that I pay attention to in a game, so it's by no means a deal breaker for me.


Gameplay: Ah, now here is where Half-Life's meat is (along with its story.) It was universally praised for its polished and fun mix of shooting and puzzles, and for raising the standards of FPS gameplay completely. In my opinion, some of this praise still holds true, but Half-Life's gameplay has aged well in some aspects and not so well in others.
By far, the best aged part of the gameplay is the shooting. It still feels good after 16 years, with a nice variety of weapons that are all fun to use (shotgun FTW!) and continue to remain useful throughout the 10 hour campaign. There are a nice variety of enemies, too, from the Xen aliens (all with different attacks,) and the HECU Marines, who at the time were considered to have some of the most advanced AI in any game, and still pose a challenge to fight (although this is more due to their incredibly annoying tendency to move around a ton making them hard to hit then for their AI.) There are also boss fights, a staple of 90's FPS's. Thankfully, these boss fights are mostly done well, with the exception that I feel that the final boss's solution is a bit too obtuse. What hasn't aged well are the puzzles. While I don't mind puzzles in FPS games to mix up the gameplay, the puzzles here are platforming puzzles, another 90's staple. These puzzles feel like they really break up the otherwise great pacing of the game, and I always feel a bit annoyed whenever one comes across. However, they are thankfully short and shouldn't be a huge problem to master. The game also includes friendly NPCs, another reason it was lauded, but these NPCs are rather useless except to move the plot along.  Overall, Half-Life's gameplay is still enjoyable, even if it does feel a bit dated.

Story/Atmosphere: The other reason Half-Life was so well-received was for its (at the time,) immersive atmosphere and well-written story. This still holds true, mostly. You play as Gordon Freeman, Theoretical Physicist and employee of the top-secret Back Mesa Research Facility, a government facility deep beneath the New Mexico desert. During a normal day at work, an experiment goes horribly wrong, causing a fictional resonance cascade" and opening a tear between Black Mesa and the alien borderworld of Xen. You must find a way to close the dimensional tear and save Earth
date: while battling the hostile aliens and US soldiers sent by the government to liquidate the personnel and cover up the incident. The plot itself
hoursPlayed: is still well-written and still solid even today. Even with some hilariously entertaining voice-acting it still gets its hooks into you and manages to keep you interested for the well-executed twist ending. The atmosphere

reviewText:
This game is a masterpiece. I'm pretty sure I'm not the first to say that, but it really feels like one. Many things in this game make it what it is. First, the gameplay in this game is just marvelous, you can't feel closer to the game with his amazing mechanisms, shooting, jumping and everything you can do, it just feels right. It seems like it's really you that control the game and that the final result, good or bad, is always the product of your moves. With a great shooting and movement mechanism, everything feels right.

Secondly, another thing you can't complain about this game, its story. The story of Half-Life, the one that gave birth to this amazing franchise, is just a beautiful piece of work. It fully accomplishes its mission to take you to another world. With the fact that, Gordon Freeman, the character which you control, is entirely in your possession feels like you are in this story and you have to power to change it. The game doesn't even have cutscenes so everything is seen from your point of view. The story is captivating with the reasons that it treats the alien subject differently from most stories told on this subject. It contains a government conflict trying to hide the alien-incident, a mysterious G-Man, the man who watches you and with the discovery of the alien world which makes you realize some secrets about them. Maybe after all, they're not what we thought... So many questions will fly in your head and will give you the desire to continue this mysterious story.

Thirdly, I have to talk about the graphics and the level design. Those both, like everything I said before, are just truly great. While the graphics may be considered ugly" or "old" are for me still beautiful even if this game is from 1998. With great details

reviewText:
What's the first thing that comes to mind, when reviewing a video game? Well, for me, it has to be the visual world that captures the core of our imaginations. And with this little gem called Half-Life, it's no exception that this game continues to boggle the mind and leave people wondering. There is more heart, creativity and scientific ingenuity there is in this one title than there is in most series and is arguably Valve's greatest achievement. (With over 50 game awards, it's a strong justification). Half-Life isn't just one of the greatest FPS games of all time. It's not because Half-Life is one of the best purchases you can ever get on Steam. Half-Life is quite simply, one of the greatest games ever made.

When compared to certain FPS games in the past and modern times, which both heavily rely on long-winded cutscenes to glorify the main plotline, Half-Life annihilates this compulsed aspect, by detailing the plotlines that keeps the player still in control of the first-person viewpoint, leaving the cutscenes rolling while you still have full access to the gameplay and character controllability. For clarification, You will see through the eyes of Gordon Freeman at all times.

The game is a constant puzzle; leaving the player to work at tasks that involve being locked into battle and overall puzzle solving to advance through the many challenges that wait up ahead. Most of the time, the story illuminates the puzzles by the actions to proceed, such as maze scenarios and building boxes to use as staircases. Though Half-Life has short-lived loading screens from time to time after leaving a certain area for a new one, the game has no levels. But, to make up for this traditional concept, the game is split into a number of mind-boggling chapters filled with rich story glory.

To start off with this game's story, you're none other than Gordon Freeman. A young man who holds a Ph.D in theoretical physics who starts his daily grind back at the Black Mesa Research Facility; a fictional complex that is stranded in a remote desert located in the suburbs of New Mexico. Arriving late for work yet again, you take the tram system around the Black Mesa Research Facility and at this point, objectives that his game has fulfilled such as breath-taking visuals and movie quality animation begins to blossom. The tram sequence at the beginning of the game can only be summed up in one word; Incredible. It's as if the things that come flying at you from every angle and position, almost reminiscent of watching an action-packed movie, along with the credits of the producer's names proudly fading in and out on the corner of the screen.

As you make your first step in the heavily secured facility, you're constantly reminded that you put on your Hazardous Enviromental suit, or the H.E.V suit for short. While all things are hunky-dory, those things soon turn to the worst very soon. After a failed experiment, involving a collision between a rare intergalactic specimen from another dimension with an Anti-Mass Spectrometer, the Black Mesa facility falls in ruins, meaning you are one of the only key survivors of the infamous ''Black Mesa Incident''. And with this, alien life-forms from the dimension of ''Xen'' are pulled from their dimension into ours and are running amok the ruined facility, along with the Army that storm the place after the gone, haywired facility's emergency call has been echoed. This of course doesn't make things any easier and you soon find yourself battling both the aliens and army.

While there isn't exactly much to complain about, I would admit that guiding the chickened-out scientists and professors around the facility can be quite a pain now and again, as well as the alien life-form, Vortigaunt, from which you would have to wait and be patient for them to wreck down wooden doors in front of you, as you are not capable of doing that yourself. (You do start off with a crowbar, right?) As well as I'm probably not the only one who made the same mistake by killing them through a small opening, before they did in fact begin to tear down the doors. But then again, this is where the used scripted intermissions started to show, so that's an added bonus.

For the long run, I've had fun and joy both reviewing this amazing game and playing this amazing game. If you haven't play Half-Life and you're not familiar with Half-Life, it's still a massive recommendation from me.

reviewText: This game is a Milestone for FPS's, and Video Games in general. Although I prefer the Portal Series (and HL2 was far surperior to its predecessor), this game still deserves the praise it gets. I'll be honest, this game's controls haven't aged the best; everything is slippery and way too fast. But, with a game from '98, that is to be expected. Despite minor hiccups in the control department, everything else checks out: the graphics look great for the time and still look good today, the story is interesting (even if it's rarely explained), and it can be very challenging at times. Almost everyone has already played this game so me telling you to get it won't do much, but still I implore everyone who hasn't played this gem to pick it up ASAP.

reviewText:
Half-Life I was a game I'd heard a lot about, but I had neer played anything like it (the closest was probably 007: Goldeneye, so I wasn't quite certain of what I was getting into at first, but the Half-Life collection was on sale for only some $15, so I figured I'd take a risk.
And I'm so glad I did.  I decided, on a whim, to play it on its hardest difficulty, and I recommend you do the same, because it's just hard enough to make you be really careful, but not so hard to bring you to throw your controller across the room.
I'll address my thoughts on Half-Life I in the tradition of YouTube reviewer The Completionist:

Story 9/10
A la Zelda I, story takes a backseat in Half Life I, and I personally really like that.  There IS a story, but unlike in so many triple-A titles, it doesn't demand so much attention that the rest is neglected.  The story that exists can basically be summed up like this:
You are Gordon Freeman, a scientist with special training in the use of a power-augmenting suit, working in a top-secret facility known as Black Mesa.  After an experiment goes horribly wrong, alien creatures with no greater purpose than to kill and infect humans begin appearing around the facility, and you, as one of the only able-bodied people alive, must fight your way out of the death trap that Black Mesa has become.  But along the way, you notice a mysterious man watching your every move...
And that's it.  Most of the developments throughout the game are finding out one teensy little detail about Black Mesa's past through a stray word in normal dialogue or through coming across the aforementioned mysterious figure who watches you throughout the game.
I love it.  Having the story be so simple lets the gameplay and puzzles take a much larger role in my mind.  Instead of thinking to myself, I have to get past this puzzle so that I can know what happened to Jim
date: I'm thinking hmm...if I only have 27 health and I need to get past the lightning-throwing alien with only two bullets in my revolver
recommended: how quick will I need to fire?  And how close should I get?  Are there more enemies around him?  Maybe I could sneak past him and find a stock of ammo..." and so on.  The game prompts the player to think so much

reviewText: The first thing anybody is going to notice in this game is the graphics. They're very dated, and sit somewhere in between Playstation and Playstation 2, but don't let this turn you off from this classic. I originally bought this just to fill the gap in story before Half Life 2, but found it to be an extremely fun and intermittently terrifying old-school survival horror FPS. This comes complete with the ability to Friendly-fire on any civillian you wish and enemies you'll come to hate, placed so strategically as to force you to go away from the health pack you desperately need because you don't have enough health to face them in the first place.

reviewText: Half-Life is quite possibly one of the most important first-person shooters ever created. You're not a space marine: you're a scientist fighting for your life. You truly feel alone when your only companion--be it a scientist or one of the many security guards trapped with you--bites the dust, leaving you to fend for yourself. reviewText:
This game is a classic. It doesn't matter if I recommend it or not, you should probably at least try it.

As most of you know, you are Gordon Freeman, scientist or something from Black Mesa and you basically save the ♥♥♥♥ing world. This first-person shooter combines a wide variety of weapons - Assault rifles, SMGs, pistols, grenades and crowbars with an amazing story and perfectly crafted levels. I understand why this game is regarded as a classic, the levels are truly made beautifully.

Aside from being a great single player game, it also spawned a lot of community made mods, which were later created into standalone games. Popular ones like Counter-Strike, Day of Defeat, Team Fortress Classic and even Ricochet all started from Half-Life.

To be honest, though, with the amount of praise it gets, I somehow expected a lot more, even though I knew it's an old game and I was a bit disappointed. Movement also felt a bit slippery.

Overall, It's definitely not a bad idea to buy it.

reviewText:
This game is a masterpiece. I'm pretty sure I'm not the first to say that, but it really feels like one. Many things in this game make it what it is. First, the gameplay in this game is just marvelous, you can't feel closer to the game with his amazing mechanisms, shooting, jumping and everything you can do, it just feels right. It seems like it's really you that control the game and that the final result, good or bad, is always the product of your moves. With a great shooting and movement mechanism, everything feels right.

Secondly, another thing you can't complain about this game, its story. The story of Half-Life, the one that gave birth to this amazing franchise, is just a beautiful piece of work. It fully accomplishes its mission to take you to another world. With the fact that, Gordon Freeman, the character which you control, is entirely in your possession feels like you are in this story and you have to power to change it. The game doesn't even have cutscenes so everything is seen from your point of view. The story is captivating with the reasons that it treats the alien subject differently from most stories told on this subject. It contains a government conflict trying to hide the alien-incident, a mysterious G-Man, the man who watches you and with the discovery of the alien world which makes you realize some secrets about them. Maybe after all, they're not what we thought... So many questions will fly in your head and will give you the desire to continue this mysterious story.

Thirdly, I have to talk about the graphics and the level design. Those both, like everything I said before, are just truly great. While the graphics may be considered ugly" or "old" are for me still beautiful even if this game is from 1998. With great details

reviewText:
First off if your tired of FPS that are like COD, Battlefield, etc than Half-Life is the game for you
Pros:
-Very original story (It is told through dialogue, and your always in the First-Person).
-Excellent gameplay (HL's gameplay is a mixture of stealth at some sequences and all out guns blazing in others)
-All elements to me are original
-Cool protagonist
-Pretty awesome weapons
-Challenging enemies in well designed maps

Cons:
-Some minor glitches (like getting stuck on a wall which can be fixed by shooting your weapon) (This was all on my version, not sure if it will appear in yours)
-Clunky platforming sections (There will be some parts of the game where platforming is required, and even if it looks like you can make the jump, you slip sometimes of the ledge).
-No Half-Life 3

Overall 9/10
Half-Life is an excellent game, but some minor glitches and the platforming sections frustrated me a little.
Half-Life is a masterpiece and not only do a recommend Half-Life 1, but buy Half-Life 1 Anthology and The Orange Box for Gordon Freeman's journey in full

Now stay tuned for my review of Half-Life: Opposing Force...
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: The plot isn't terribly hard to follow, but it rattles along and is absolutely compelling. The environments are varied, from office complexes in Black Mesa to experimental labs, to a low-gravity alien realm. The weapons are realistic and easy to use; the crowbar splinters boxes and fractures skulls as it should - the pistol is weedy, but a welcome addition, grenades are thrown as they should, and the shotgun is satisfyingly powerful. The later weapons are brilliant, with my favourite of the gauss gun, which can charge up and take out helicopters if you do it just right. The guns are acquired at a good pace, although you don't get the most powerful one until very late in the game, which feels like a shame.\nIt's tremendously absorbing - you really feel immersed in the levels. The music helps, but it's a bit sporadic - you'll get some great music when you're coming up to a key bit, and then it'll die down.\nWhile there is variety of landscape and it is excellently created-the bareness of the offices and labs except of monsters and the general coldness of the facility as well as the chilling music creates a dark, sorrowful atmosphere. Your almost complete loneliness (apart from the occasional scientist or security guard) is capped by the chilling messages inscribed on the wall, 'Surrender, Freeman.' 'Freeman your dead' by the military.

Not much to say about Half-Life that hasn't been said yet, but it's a classic. While it's not the best FPS, it's definitely one of the best. Valve's finest creation to date! It's a long, challenging game and will keep you entertained for years to come. This is the game that got me into Valve in 2004, I believe (I first played this on PS2, a while after RtCW on Xbox).

However, I do not recommend buying this game by itself - buy one of the bundles. The Half-Life Complete bundle is $40, but comes with 11 games (1. Half-Life 1 2. Opposing Force 3. Blue Shift 4. Half-Life Source 5. Half-Life Deathmatch Source 6. Half-Life 2 7. Episode 1 8. Episode 2 9
Half-Life 2 Deathmatch 10. Half-Life 2 Lost Coast 11. Team Fortress Classic). Deathmatch Source and Lost Coast don't appear in the bundle contents, but they're still added to your library. The other bundle, Half-Life 1 Anthology, comes with Half-Life and it's two expansion packs (Opposing Force and Blue Shift) for only $5 extra. Considering the expansions are $5 a pop, you get one for free by buying it that way.

reviewText:
So...this is what all the commotion is about....yes I know I'm late to the party by several years....hahahaha

Single player is great, if I were playing it on release date, which is apparently in 1998 or at least somewhere around there. Mutilplayer seems to be dead, I can see one server in Australia that appears to be alive but no one playing on it....there are other servers overseas but I can't stand playing with 300+ ping...

But still not bad in this era, like lots of interesting little interaction with objects that some of these newer games don't have. I also like how when you blow a body up, the body parts go flying in bits and pieces, unlike some of these newer games where you blow something up and they just go flying as a whole(or nothing happens)....

It's got an interesting storyline I guess. Those aliens remind me of the flood from Halo....hahaha

Yeah overal, I suppose I liked it.

reviewText:
half-life 1
possibly the greatest FPS ever made (sue me COD fanboys)
when i was a teenager i wasted literally years of time in this game on my old 350Mhz pentium 2 tower with 64MB of RAM in 640x480 res with a 2MB graphics card

this is a classic and no real review is required but for completion sake i will write one anyway

pros:
this game will run on literally any computer made after 2000 even without a dedicated GPU
multiplayer is fun when you can find someone to play with
the graphics still hold up today in my opinion if you use direct 3D or open GL mode at max res
the level design was exquisite for its time and is still good today
you get a wide range of weapons to use from the legendary crowbar to an alien beehive
(did i mention i hate bees!!!)
the gore from falls and explosions (or even the crowbar) is still unmatched in detail by most modern games
the voice acting is really good for the time
by adjusting the text in the speech files sometimes you can make characters swear at you
you can even shoot a tanks main cannon and watch alien guts fly everywhere
the rerplay value is high on this one and i would play it any day


cons:
it sometimes doesnt work properly on newer computers and operating systems
most of the time you will have ammo for the guns that are all but useless late in the game
(ever played shotgun vs helicopter?)
the end boss is near impossible to beat the first time until you look up a walkthrough
the protection missions (protect this scientist from aliens) are hard as ♥♥♥♥ because tanking is not a useful tactic
headcrabs come out of nowhere before you can shoot them so you WILL take damage




bottom line:
get this game
get this game
get this game
why are you still reading this
get this game
get this game
seriously what are you waiting for vote this review as helpful and buy the game its only a dollar or 2

It has a simplistic story expecially now in today's standards and the gunplay feels a bit dated now. It's not the masterpiece that it maybe once was back in the day. This is still a must play for any fan of fps games and i don't mean play it for 30 minutes and never touch again like most people do.\n7/10 (Good)

reviewText:
I'll be honest; I didn't love Half-Life at first.

Maybe it was the fact that I played this game in 2016, 18 years after its initial release in 1998. Perhaps it was the serviceable but definitely outdated controls  I had to deal with, along with some annoying bugs and glitches. It didn't click for me. But after about an hour of getting used to everything, here's what I realized: Half-Life is real nice. Almost everything wrong with the game comes from technological limitations of the 90s. Graphics really start to show the wear-and-tear of 18 years; but they aren't bad enough to distract from the general gameplay.

I can't make any more complaints about Half-Life simply because the sum of its parts makes it such a good game. The story still entertains and is delivered well, throwing out lengthy cutscenes and text crawls in favor of gameplay-based storytelling. Enemy AI was amazing for its time and still functions well today; a variety of weapons and unique, challenging level designs keep things interesting through the course of this game. Most importantly, Half-Life retains a remarkable sense of immersion. You do things of your own volition - you never feel like the game is telling you to do something.

The best and most surprising aspect of this is its genuine difficulty. Make no mistake about it, scrubs: Half-Life is HARD. The game will throw you in tough situations that make you get off your silly high horse and think; try to play this game with the Doom mentality of run-and-gun and you'll get instantly wrecked by its puzzles and smart enemy placement. Playing through Half-Life in 2016 was a chore; it was a struggle. Most importantly, though? It was a genuinely fascinating, enjoyable little 10+ hour trip into the world of an FPS that revolutionized EVERYTHING in the world of video games upon its release. If it were remastered and retweaked today (read: Black Mesa), it would still be one of the best shooters of any generation of gaming.

A definite must-play if you want to stop being a filthy scrub.
Rating: 7 spooky alien baby-heads out of 10.

reviewText:
What to say about Half Life.....

Okay, let me say that I originally bought the game's Game of the Year edition(included Team Fortress Classic) back in...... what? '98? Early '99 maybe? Anyway...... The hours you see logged for this game under Steam are WAY off. I didn't make the switch from WON to Steam until it was forced on us in 2004.

What to say about the game itself.... put simply; it's AMAZING! When I saw the initial opening scenes..... I was blown away.

16 years later, I'm still playing it, and I still find it a bit of a challenge.

Half Life re-defined the FPS genre, and in such a positive way, it is still selling. It can be argued that the graphics are dated, and perhapse they are. Personally, I don't think so. I think they are as much a part of the game as the abilities you get as Gordon Freeman.

Half Life won over 50 Game of the Year awards, and rightly so. If you enjoy FPS games, and this game isn't in your collection..... GET IT! It has a great blend of action, stuff to destroy, things to make you think, and lots of hidden Easter Eggs.

reviewText: Short version: good, but probably not as good as you've heard. Still get it\n\nLong version: It's a well-made game, and it's very clever in terms of the gameplay (i.e. boss fights are a bit more complicated than in most games, you have to think around the location of the fight, not the health" of the boss persay). The graphics are as good as they need to be
date: they may seem a bit dated
hoursPlayed: my only problem with this game is that it's very gimmicky and way overhyped (I could say the same about half-life 2). Is it a great shooter? yes. One of the best of it's era? Sure. The best shooter ever? God no! I personally enjoyed games like doom and Bioshock more
voteText:
because they don't try to skirt around the fun of shooting things with how "groundbreaking" they are get in the way of their fun.

General pros and Cons:

Pros:
+ It's a good shooter
+ well-done setpieces that involve the player
+ Great worldbuilding
+ Good piece of gaming history
+ Varied and interesting gamplay

Cons:
- Slow paced
- Unfair at times
- Breeds a fanbase prone to overhyping it

Worth the purchase on sale or bundled with the expansions"

reviewText: The success of this game started it all for Valve. Team Fortress, Counter-Strike and countless amounts of other mods. It had become a hallmark of FPS quality for many years to come until Half-Life 2 came out to raise the bar even higher. This legendary status helps to alleviate the ravages of time the graphics have suffered. But, as any Counter-Strike player will tell you, it is not that bad considering the age of the game, it's still approachable for younger players. The game's design is very variable and interactive, which cannot be said about a myriad of modern shooters. The remarkable sound and authentic music will help to create a memorable, mysterious, sci-fi atmosphere. Xen, being the most criticized part of the game, seemed quite enjoyable to me. It offers a much needed diversion from the rest of the game, most of which takes place in steel corridors. This game represents a milestone, thanks to which a series of events lead to the creation of our beloved Steam. Praise be Half-Life, the Almighty! :)
