reviewText:
Half-Life 1 is a really nice game.
It got released in 1998 and so it looks really old but it can be a lot of fun. Half-Life is a classic.
You are a scientist called Gordon Freeman. One day you are involved in a critical test which goes terribly wrong and opens portals to the boarderland Xen. From that moment on, aliens invade earth and you find yourself in chaos and try to get out alive.

The singleplayer was revolutionary at the time because it has a continious story without cutscenes. I also like that there are a lot of enemy-types. The weapons are all really balanced (except gluongun) and fun to use. The story develops as you proceed in the game. It gets more and more mysterious and suspense.
In Half-Life you are mostly on your own and travel through many interessting environments. Sometimes the maps can be a bit confusing but in the end you will have a nice final and it feels great to finish the game.

In my opinion Half-Life's multiplayer is very very good. I played it a very long time and it has a great learning-curve. In Half-Life you have very dynamic gameplay with fast movement, air-control, excessive wallbanging and spawnkilling. It can be a really great feel to dominate and control the whole map. In Half-Life you can play many styles.. aggressive like a berserker but also slow and silent. It's possible to break the enemies advantage by clever ambushing and by hitting well aimed headshots. Since there are many different weapons you can always find different ways to deal with your enemy. Each weapon is very different and good in special situations. Also the maps are all very different to each other. Each map has it's own great design and unique gameplay.

Conclusion:
I recommend you to try Half-Life on LAN with friends, because it's a lot of fun to play against enemies of equal skill. Since it has a great learning-curve you have to get into the game a bit.
If you want to play online I recommend you to edit your config-file so you can have a field of view of 110 degrees and direct weapon-bindings. On most servers (Adrenaline Gamer Mod) you can use bunnyhop. Since they patched Half-Life you are no longer able to code bunnyhop-scripts in your config. So if you want a working bhop you have to use a macro programm like autohotkey or maybe your keyboard-driver. The other easier way to use bhop is to disable automatic updates and patch back half-life to an older version (still works online).
Half-Life has a lot of mods and there is a lot of custom content (player and weapon-models, maps, effects and hud-elements). I recommend you to install good visible custom crosshairs and use simple explosion sprites.
Regarding mods I can recommend you Adrenaline Gamer, Sven-Coop 3.0 (because it has the original Half-Life weapons and basicly is a coop mod for Half-Life), The Specialists (a Matrix-styled mod) and Frontline Force.
There are also a lot great singleplayer mods. I can recommend you Half-Life Invasion, Escape from the Darkness, Paranoia, Todesangst, ETC 1 and 2, Sweet Half-Life and a lot more.
Seriously there are a lot good mods out there..
All in all for me this game is a must have. So if you don't mind the old graphics and take some time to understand the game.. I think you will like it!
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Shooting creatures and crawling through air vents.

Half-Life is Valve's critically acclaimed debut title.

You play as a physicist Gordon Freeman, who survived an experiment that hadn't really turned out too well. Of course you are supposed to fix that, so you're going to shoot weird things and solve puzzles.

If you play it for the first time now, so many years after the release, it's somewhat likely that you're going to find it boring or repetitive at one point or another - but taking into account its age, it's a game that absolutely deserves the praise and awards it received.

reviewText: I have played this game alot. And I truly mean alot. And its the same game, too! Yet for some reason, I always come back for more. Hell, I've even started seeing how far I can play on only one life; if I die I restart. There is just something so near perfect about the collective combat, atmostphere, level design, audio and visual design, and everything else that come together in a beautiful collection of Valve's hard work in their glory days. It is clear that this game provided much inspiration for future FPS games.  Buy and play it at all costs.\n\nP.S. The multiplayer is actually pretty fun too ;D

reviewText:
When I first gave Half Life a shot, I thought to myself: This was released in 1998? Because I was very impressed with what was developed almost 2 decades ago. The original Half Life is nothing short of amazing for the single player experience that many shooters today wish they had.
I was able to understand the story here more than in Half Life 2, and actually being inside Black Mesa when something goes horribly wrong. Half Life also has extensive DLC content to add to the overall game

The Original Half Life gets a 9/10. You get get this game along with the Half Life Collection for $5 when on sale. I recommend the Original Half Life for those who are looking for a great single-player experience.

Until next review!    ~Stealth 1548

reviewText:
Half-Life is a FPS, but not a average FPS, this game brings in shooting and platforming at the right times, sometimes managing the jumping puzzles can be hard, even when the answer is in plain sight and hard to see, completing it feels satisfying. The game can be difficult espically at times when coming to some parts (unless your on easy) making that feel good when you complete it too. The soundtrack is a good part of this game too, and by good, I mean amazingly good. Some of my favorite songs in the game are the following: Hazardous Enviroments, Nuclear Mission Jam, Klaxon Beat, Diabolical Adrenaline Guitar, and Jungle Drums. Overall, being one of the best (and first!) Valve Software games ever, this game gets a 9/10.

reviewText: This game still holds as one of the best first person shooters, specially because of it's multiplayer. It hasn't aged that well, unlike it's successor. Glitches in the single player campaign can be very annoying, but if you like old games, you must play this. It's a very long game, has little focus on story, so the action is nonstop as you travel trough a lot of different environments, the gameplay never gets boring. And if you already played Black Mesa Source, I still recommend this just because of the multiplayer.\nThe multiplayer is very unique and fun. The different kinds of alien weaponry and the possibility to use some of then to move and jump around makes it very hard to master. I always return to play it because the multiplayer on modern war games always bores me, trying to be realistic and balanced, while in Half-Life you just make a mess with ridiculously overpowered weapons and movement mechanics, it's fast, it's awesome. Half-Life 2 Deathmatch was just not the same in comparison. If Valve decides to make Half-Life 3's multiplayer just like the first game, with more maps, more overpowered alien weapons, faster movement, and a remake of the crossfire map, it will be the best multiplayer game ever, outselling all Call of Duty games combined.

reviewText:
It is unfortunate to say this, but as great a game as Half-Life is, time has not been good to it. When I played the game, it was sad to see how old the game has become. Nonetheless, this is the game to shatter all games for almost a decade.
Video games have so much to owe to Half-Life, every single FPS that has come out since then, owes something to Half-life.
If you played Half-Life rather thoughtlessly, you may think that the game is seriously overrated, but the story, the dialouge, and the characters in Half-Life are very subtle. Don't expect this game to parade itself as the best PC game of all time. It's modest that way.
We can't really say much about the graphics or sound or the character models of Half-Life, as this game IS from 1998, but this game is big where is counts. The gameplay is solid, the story is quiet, - yet brilliant - and the level design is incredible. If you want to know how to make the best game the world has ever seen, go to Half-Life. I wish game designers of today would use this as a model, because you just don't get better.
I may be raving about how great the game is, and in that case I have something BAD to say about it...
I hate the bloody ladders in this game.

reviewText:
Half Life is a zombie game in the perspective of one of those responsible for it's origins. In the Black Mesa scientific research and developemt facility (Interesting Banter: Black Mesa roughly translates to Black Table, with Mesa meaning Table in spanish. #TheMoreYouKnow) Gordon Freeman, age 27, inadvertently causes the apocalypse, when a rare crystal found from the facility's experiments with teleportation is places under a super-powered analyzer, which then overloads and opens a wormhole to an alien dimension full of creatures that leech onto your head and gain control over your body, creating zombies.
Lost intrest yet? No? Good.
Armed with a crowbar, a mech suit, and a series of shooty-shooty bang bang tubes, you face the onslaught, prepared to get to the surface and call for help. Does this go well? Buy the game and see.*

This game is old. Like, 1998 old. But when it came out, it revolutionalised the gaming industry with it's unique storytelling and gameplay style. It is a first person shooter that will be remembered for years to come, despite it being 16 next month.

However, this game can be PUNISHINGLY dificult, especiallly in later levels. No doubt will you find yourself wishing you'd picked an easier difficulty at some point in the game.
Having said this, though, Half Life is still damn enjoyable, even to this day.

Verdict: This is a damn fine shooter.
8/10. Would happily play again and again a few times.

*SPOILERS  The US Army intend to neutralize the threat by killing every living, undead, and alien thing in the facility, It's fun. You get to shoot the same 3 soldier models over and over. :D

reviewText:
Since I first heard about this game, I thought it is pretty cool and didn't really pay attention behind what's so great about Half-Life. Now, when I start playing it, I felt that this game has alot of riches and opprtunities that everyone will enjoy and no wonder Half-Life 1 has over 50 Game of the Year Awards.

First is for the pros, which this game has alot of them, the backstory and the characters behind the game are interesting, the gameplay is enjoyable and I have a good time with powerful weapons and the graphics are so breathtaking such as the canyon scene I saw, it was very unique and cool and for the planet Xen, I cannot believe that world was so out of place and drag me in behind the bizarre biological life that the aliens have. For the best part is that it doesn't feel the modern Call of Duty games such as Black Ops and Modern Warfare, its a different character as being a  scientist not a hardcore soldier that's how it is for this game, it's uniquely different and the Half-Life experience is totally out of this world.

Well, its not perfect, there are a few minor mistakes behind the game, sometimes when I interact with certain people and ask them to follow, they would rather stay in place and lose me whether I go and I became frustrated for it wastes time for my progression in the game. So, these were minor problems that Valve will improve throughout the new versions of Half-Life.

In the end, I got to say that this game definitely worths my time and money and I can't wait to enjoy other Half-Life expansions such as Opposing Force and Blue Shift. Also for its sequel, Half-Life 2 and it's remaining episodes, 1-2.

For the scale from 1 to 10, I'll give it a 10/10.

reviewText: I absolutely love this game. Almost everything about this game is ahead of it's time. Gameplay, Graphics, and the AI. The guards in the Science lab (Black Mesa) follow you well, and do whatever they can to help you, and their not Half-Bad at it. (Bad pun) The roaches flock to dead bodies, and run away from you, and your flashlight for example. And the military forces distract and then flank you too, which adds some difficulty. This game will occasionally laugh in your face while you try to do something to progress, but it's okay because even though you usually end up dying in the end of the trick, there is usually an autosave just before the trick to give you the chance to correct your mistake. You can also save whenever you want to, and load back to any of the saves you have made.And believe me, you might just need to do that a few times. Sometimes you got a part, and then you can't get past it because you have almost no health by the time you get there. But it's okay, this game is fun and satisfying. You can also make corpses explode with only a crowbar, and that alone is enough to make me get this game. 420/10\n\nAlso, for some reason, I think I was the only person in the world who actually dug around in the video settings a bit, and you can actually play through the whole game with better looking weapons with clear textures, and they look entirely different. And you can actually read the words BLACK MESA on the guards' badges. I played through the entirety of the game with the HD models, so when I saw playthroughs and screenshots of the game with people using the low quality models I was kind of confused.

reviewText: The best chapter of the Half-Life saga, a masterpiece. A 15-20 hours-long adventure that will never cease to entertain you. I played it on hard and it was very challenging (took me over 20 hours and hundreds of deaths). The old GoldSrc engine has an unique feel to it - super fast movement, strafing like in quake and very responsive controls. Also, the performance is very good and you will get extreme framerates on any computer. The graphics are good old-fashioned quake3-style graphics. I higly recommend you play this before playing HL: Source, so that you get to experience the unique feel of the old engine.

reviewText:
This is it, the beginning of the legend, even though it is quite dated by today’s standards the game aged like a fine wine and gameplay feels solid. Here you get to know how to the amazing universe of Half Life and Portal started and the consequences of the chain of events Gordon got himself into.

A very bad aspect of the game is that many friendly human models and voices are the same throughout the game and said people will be torn to pieces and blasted full of holes and that somewhat gives a bizarre feeling and it makes a bit confusing to be able to tell who is the real Eli Vance and Kleiner but I guess technology was more limited back then.

The game itself tries to combine puzzles, shooting and a bit of sci-fi horror into a nice little mix. You might be trying to figure out how to turn on the water to some device but you know that when you go back to activate it you will to pass through those alien clawed tentacles of death or you will be having a flame throwing gargatuan on your tail and you have to see how to dispose of him while running like a mouse.

Small creatures will always be jumping on you and making you keep an eye out in every little hole and corner and the huge enemies will make you run and hide to safety giving that chasing sensation. In terms of enemy variety it’s a pretty nice selection going from generic army thugs and ninjas to energy shooting aliens, grunts that fire a barrage of homing “bees” to you and even vehicles and artillery strikes.

Every gun in here has its purpose, you want to explode a few barrels but not waste precious ammo? Use the normal gun. Want to see your enemies go up in pieces with some traps? Place some remote charges here and there and then cover the door ways in optic mines. A huge firefight got you trapped in a corner? Well thanks to a grenade barrel in your assault rifle you can noobtube your way out of trouble. But wait, massive ordinance is being deployed on poor little you? Well those huge aliens, tanks and helicopters won’t expect a guided missile on their face, or will they? In that case they should be no match for a charged radioactive shot or maybe your Gluon Hyper Beam that can rival the most legendary of Pokémon.
If all fails, nothing says DIE like a crowbar to the face.

There’s not much to say about the environments they are quite varied and include even ice parts and water parts where you will have to face the terrors of the deep with your “water usable” weapons only. Basically you go through offices, warehouses, factories, sewers a bit of desert canyon and at last the mysterious and bizarre Xen where everything came out of Gabe Newell’s fever dreams and rules of gravity allow you to be fabulous.

TL;DR: You should play this, see how old things are done right  and explode the microwave casserole.

reviewText:
PROS:
- Straight-foward story
- Enjoyable gameplay
- Perfect balance between ammo conservation and limitations
- Player-friendly interactions

CONS:
- Gordon feels too high over other characters
- Story path is never explained to you

OVERVIEW:
This game is really ♥♥♥♥ing good. It's pretty high up there, but NOT at the top. (Grab your pitchforks!) Half-Life is the first installment into the series and does not fail to impress. With easy to look at and understand graphics and hands-down some of the finest crafted gameplay in any game i've ever played, this game is something I could replay anytime. Most of you should already know the story and its characters, only because its a Valve game, so i'll spare the story details. While playing through Half-Life, you may notice the crazy balance between ammo and limits. There are a lot of risk-taking moments and sometimes even have you leaving to backtrack for more ammo, which does not feel tedious at all. All interactions in this game are centered around YOU. It feels like you are important to this world, like you really are trying to save it. Overall it just makes for fine story-telling. As for Gordon himself and the way other characters perceive him, it just feels dumb. EVERY other character just feels like they are lower than you, which doesn't show a challenge in the story. I don't know if Valve tried to play a safe-route when it came to the story, but it disapointed me when you felt higher than everyone. It's like having a route, A to B. At B there is a super weapon that you need but instead of walking that route, the game just brings it to you and it does not feel so rewarding.

This game is great and highly enjoyable. I'd state my cons at more of a personal pinpoint, but it's really up to you on how you feel about it.

reviewText: Almost 20 years ago now, Half-Life released and it forever changed the First Person Shooter. Much has been said about HL and it's all true. Doom and Wolfenstein popularized the genre as a whole, and HL changed the way we saw level-design in FPS as a whole. A big, linear map and a background story made the game what it is and damn if it isn't one of the finest games out there. The game is cheap enough even outside sales, pick it up and enjoy one of the best games from generations before (just be careful of the underwater monster, heart-attack inducing ♥♥♥♥).

There’s not much to say about the environments they are quite varied and include even ice parts and water parts where you will have to face the terrors of the deep with your “water usable” weapons only. Basically you go through offices, warehouses, factories, sewers a bit of desert canyon and at last the mysterious and bizarre Xen where everything came out of Gabe Newell’s fever dreams and rules of gravity allow you to be fabulous.

TL;DR: You should play this, see how old things are done right  and explode the microwave casserole.

reviewText:
Half Life is a zombie game in the perspective of one of those responsible for it's origins. In the Black Mesa scientific research and developemt facility (Interesting Banter: Black Mesa roughly translates to Black Table, with Mesa meaning Table in spanish. #TheMoreYouKnow) Gordon Freeman, age 27, inadvertently causes the apocalypse, when a rare crystal found from the facility's experiments with teleportation is places under a super-powered analyzer, which then overloads and opens a wormhole to an alien dimension full of creatures that leech onto your head and gain control over your body, creating zombies.
Lost intrest yet? No? Good.
Armed with a crowbar, a mech suit, and a series of shooty-shooty bang bang tubes, you face the onslaught, prepared to get to the surface and call for help. Does this go well? Buy the game and see.*

This game is old. Like, 1998 old. But when it came out, it revolutionalised the gaming industry with it's unique storytelling and gameplay style. It is a first person shooter that will be remembered for years to come, despite it being 16 next month.

However, this game can be PUNISHINGLY dificult, especiallly in later levels. No doubt will you find yourself wishing you'd picked an easier difficulty at some point in the game.
Having said this, though, Half Life is still damn enjoyable, even to this day.

Verdict: This is a damn fine shooter.
8/10. Would happily play again and again a few times.

*SPOILERS  The US Army intend to neutralize the threat by killing every living, undead, and alien thing in the facility, It's fun. You get to shoot the same 3 soldier models over and over. :D

reviewText: Wow... just... wow. What a game we have here. Playing this in the year of 2013 (After having played the wonderful Half-Life 2 some time ago), it's still a joyful experience. The awesome narrative, level design, gunplay and even artificial intelligence still work very well, making it easy to see just how incredibly ahead of its time the game was. Some things that stood out for me in particular were the level design, which changed drastically throughout the game and helped to keep things fresh, the intense (still to this day!) combat, and especially the enemies. Not only were there many different types of enemies, each one interesting and with their very own methods of attack, but for 1998 they were an extremely intelligent bunch of baddies- especially the Special Forces soldiers, who are constantly flanking and lobbing grenades. Not only that, but I found the mini-puzzles to be quite entertaining. All in all, this is one heck of a game, and there's no wonder it's been established as a masterpiece.

reviewText: All the new age shooters (otherwise known as would-be games) seem to be coming out with a little less flare each time these days so there is only one thing left for me to do; masturb… I mean play old shooters. In Half Life you play silent protagonist number B. He differs from others because he has the power of the beard and a MIT degree that obviously had no concept of oral presentations. When it was released Half Life posed a new stage of interactive storytelling. But really it just means you’re allowed to turn away from all major plot points and stare at the wall. Still, the notion of alien invasions and government cover-ups are very popular themes as my good friend, Fox Mulder, will tell you. Instead I saw Half Life as the story of the nerds overpowering the jocks and saving the world that we desperately needed.\nHalf Life went down in history as an amazing game and the introduction of raging, hormone filled teenagers to the gaming scene via the mod Counter Strike. A spine chiller looked at in comparison to Hitler nowadays. I found myself playing through Half Life many times in the small fraction of my life I have experienced (This joke would have been better if I could say half my life) and I still have one question. Why is Gordon Freeman a hero when, during my play throughs, the scientists he is supposed to be saving served him better as meat shields? A question as mysterious to me as the G-man. Last time I was called the G-man followed the statement “you hit the spot,” during several of my ‘biology’ practices. And no, those didn’t occur at MIT.

reviewText:
The game is visually decent, especially when you consider its age.
I find the physics engine a little bit annoying at times, but otherwise it is well designed. Unfortunately, there are a few bugs that are a pain in the ♥♥♥♥. I even managed to find one that affects the gameplay drastically, preventing the player from progressing. Hopefully, latter games in the series are free from this kind of issues.
Despite that and a few other minor nuisances, I consider the technical aspect of the game to be generally good.
The plot of Half-Life is the game's strong point. As you play, it gets more tense.
I don't particularly like the multiplayer mode, but that's not really a disadvantage, since the game seems to be more focused on the single-player campaign, which is awesome.
In short, Half-Life is old, but it's worth playing. I think I'll save up some money for HL2.

reviewText:
Half Life, released in 1998 by Valve, a huge success and a game that changed FPSs forever, but is it worth your time?
Pros. and cons.

-fast paced gamplay (the game almost never slows you down)
-a good balance between puzzles and shooting
-a very good variety of weapons, enemys, and segments
-great AI
-stunning graphics (for it's time anyway)
-sound effects and gun shots are good quality, and the voice acting is good (more on that later)
-it also featured an intense multiplayer which still have servers to this day(not very many though)

cons.

-the intro of the game was a little to big
-the game becomes downright frustrating sometimes
-some frustrating bugs (like when an elevatar stops when you are still on it, you can't move)
-xen (well, maybe not so much)

And then i guess some things i feel neutral about.

-voice acting was good, but then sometimes it feels like it is flushed out by surrounding sound (which potentially is part of the story sometimes)
-the story is pretty cool, but the game kind of struggles to tell it because you could pretty much skip all of it. (personally i like it this way so it doesn't effect the pace of the gameplay)
-the music was really cool but they could have put it in more parts of the game

Overall, Valve pretty much nailed it, for it's time: 9.5/10.

But is it still an enjoyable game today?
Yes, this game has aged pretty well in most of it's categories, it's a little harder to enjoy though for most gamers.

For todays standards: 8.25/10

my personal rating for todays standards: 9.3/10

go check this one out, you will probably like it, but i would wait for a steam sale though ;)

reviewText:
Half-Life is one of those games that really stands out against a majority of titles. It's main goal is to immerse you into it's world and challenge you time after time again.

Visuals - 10/10 For the 90's, beautifully atmospheric.

Gameplay - 10/10 Fantastic gameplay, so enticing and hypnotic, you'll swear you'll forget who you were for a second.

Story - 10/10 It's not that complex of a story, something goes wrong in the facility and you have to escape. However, complexity aside, it does manage to get a premise where you, as Gordon Freeman, do not understand everything that happens to you.

Overall, recommended all the ♥♥♥♥ing way.

reviewText:
Just finished Half-Life and I must say it was quite an adventure. For being such an old game it is very good! It took a very long time to get through the whole game and the story was quite extensive and very interesting! I played this game simply because I  love the Portal series so very much! Since Portal and Half-Life are linked together I figured I would get more of an explanation as to how the two game link and while portal was never hinted to, for obvious reasons (it didn't come out for another 7 or so years, duh!), I could see how the stories linked on the simple basis of the apocolypse. I'm excited to find out the rest of the story in Half life 2!
The controls are useful and it is very nice that you can save at any point rather than just key points, this is an extremely helpful feature, especially for the ever frustrating jump climb! :P The gameplay is fun and flows pretty smoothly. I have no big problems with the run/jump style. The Story was phenomenol and I really enjoyed it! They put a lot of work and effort into building a great story line.
The Dialogue is pretty good. You never hear Gordon speak, only scientists, guards, etc. which at times is quite comical. The Level Design is also phenominal. They did a lot of work on putting out as many unique levels as possible and they did a great job. The AI is not too much of a problem and I think it was quite advanced for its time. The enemy wont shoot at you if they cant see you which is actually quite nice. They sometimes get into a more strategic formation to face me which is also good work.
The World Design, along with the level design, is phenomenol. The story is linear, but with good cause. It is a story, not an RPG choice adventure. VALVe tells the story via game and I really like it! The Graphics are absolutely lesser than now, but I love it! The nostalgia is great! I really appreciate the old game made available for current PCs because a lot of the modern games can only be supported by super computers and its really nice to be able to play a quality game on a netbook, crappy PC, etc. Finally, the sound goes along with the nostalgia and I love the 8-bit sound effects and voices and music. The music is few and far between, but that just makes it all the more appreciated.
This is definitely one of the video games you need to play. Please support this amazing company, they created Steam and many wonderful games, like Portal and Half Life. Buy this game!

The Review outline style was taken from Game Developers Tycoon. Please also consider that game for it is great! :D

reviewText:
Half Life is a zombie game in the perspective of one of those responsible for it's origins. In the Black Mesa scientific research and developemt facility (Interesting Banter: Black Mesa roughly translates to Black Table, with Mesa meaning Table in spanish. #TheMoreYouKnow) Gordon Freeman, age 27, inadvertently causes the apocalypse, when a rare crystal found from the facility's experiments with teleportation is places under a super-powered analyzer, which then overloads and opens a wormhole to an alien dimension full of creatures that leech onto your head and gain control over your body, creating zombies.
Lost intrest yet? No? Good.
Armed with a crowbar, a mech suit, and a series of shooty-shooty bang bang tubes, you face the onslaught, prepared to get to the surface and call for help. Does this go well? Buy the game and see.*

This game is old. Like, 1998 old. But when it came out, it revolutionalised the gaming industry with it's unique storytelling and gameplay style. It is a first person shooter that will be remembered for years to come, despite it being 16 next month.

However, this game can be PUNISHINGLY dificult, especiallly in later levels. No doubt will you find yourself wishing you'd picked an easier difficulty at some point in the game.
Having said this, though, Half Life is still damn enjoyable, even to this day.

Verdict: This is a damn fine shooter.
8/10. Would happily play again and again a few times.

*SPOILERS  The US Army intend to neutralize the threat by killing every living, undead, and alien thing in the facility, It's fun. You get to shoot the same 3 soldier models over and over. :D

reviewText: I quite liked playing half-life, it was quite scary, baring in mind that it was made in 1998. I found it reasonably difficult, I had to get several walkthroughs, and the combat was a bit hard and slightly boring. The enemies are very slow and their attacks are very easy to dodge, however, the combat gets much more difficult when you start fighting human enemies, who have guns. I enjoyed the first-person precision platforming, like when you're standig on the thin crate, terrified and trying your hardest not to fall off, which is fairly difficult, because you move at quite a speed and simply tapping the w key makes you go about hgalf a meter, when the crate is only a quater oif a meter. You start Half-life on a train which takes you through a whole Black Mesa factory( A company that is evil but you turn against them) The train bit is quite long, so get settled in and listen to the speaker. You can move around the train, so you can see more interesting things, like the train tracks from behind, which is VERY interesting. I bought Half-life complete so I got DLC, which I haven't played yet, so I have more content. But I really hpoe Vlve doesn't kick me off steam for not giving yheir game a perfect reveiw, because it is the best source of games I have ever used. I would rate this game at 8/10, because of those small things that i  disagreed with in the game, but, apart from those thing, I really enjoyed this game!

reviewText:
It's a revolutionary game for gaming industry. Simply a classic. Half Life is a game every FPS fan should have in their libary. It's a game that set the standard for its genre.

It's a game was far ahead of its time. Unlike other games of its time, it did not force gamers to read paragraphs or watch cutscenes that explain the game’s story. Instead, Half Life throws you right into the life of an average scientist, Gordon Freeman, who finds himself in the middle of an extraordinary adventure. Every moment in the game is experienced through the eyes of Gordon Freeman, and real-time scripted events allow the gamers to react to changes around. For its time, it was groundbreaking.

It's a game you can still enjoy today.

reviewText: Even though it's nearing 20 years old, Half-Life is still a very immersive and cinematic shooter, and years ahead of its time. The level design is great, and it feels spacious without being too open (I never got lost, which is pretty amazing given my track record). There are some great scripted events which lend to the cinematic feel, and while the game doesn't usually have music, when it does kick in it's always super hype. There are also some neat and well-designed bosses which require more that brute force to take down. One of the best single-player FPS experiences.

reviewText:
This game was a graphically impressive game back then, and to be honest it's gameplay lives up even now. It's fast paced action which will completely destroy you later on in single player if you jump into everything blindly, and that fast pace makes the multiplayer incredibly fun. It gets pretty chaotic with a lot of players. I suppose my only complaint about the multiplayer is how easy it is to get spawnkilled. Other than that, I can't think of too much wrong with the game for it's time, and I'd recommend buying it if you don't have it yet.

EDIT:
A small problem I have is when it autosaves. It sometimes does so at the worst imaginable times, like rounding a corner with a bunch of enemies while you have 1 health left. Of course one could always load the previous autosave, but it's still fairly annoying.

reviewText:
Half-Life is one of those games that really stands out against a majority of titles. It's main goal is to immerse you into it's world and challenge you time after time again.

Visuals - 10/10 For the 90's, beautifully atmospheric.

Gameplay - 10/10 Fantastic gameplay, so enticing and hypnotic, you'll swear you'll forget who you were for a second.

Story - 10/10 It's not that complex of a story, something goes wrong in the facility and you have to escape. However, complexity aside, it does manage to get a premise where you, as Gordon Freeman, do not understand everything that happens to you.

Overall, recommended all the ♥♥♥♥ing way.

reviewText: Wow... just... wow. What a game we have here. Playing this in the year of 2013 (After having played the wonderful Half-Life 2 some time ago), it's still a joyful experience. The awesome narrative, level design, gunplay and even artificial intelligence still work very well, making it easy to see just how incredibly ahead of its time the game was. Some things that stood out for me in particular were the level design, which changed drastically throughout the game and helped to keep things fresh, the intense (still to this day!) combat, and especially the enemies. Not only were there many different types of enemies, each one interesting and with their very own methods of attack, but for 1998 they were an extremely intelligent bunch of baddies- especially the Special Forces soldiers, who are constantly flanking and lobbing grenades. Not only that, but I found the mini-puzzles to be quite entertaining. All in all, this is one heck of a game, and there's no wonder it's been established as a masterpiece.

reviewText:
Just finished Half-Life and I must say it was quite an adventure. For being such an old game it is very good! It took a very long time to get through the whole game and the story was quite extensive and very interesting! I played this game simply because I  love the Portal series so very much! Since Portal and Half-Life are linked together I figured I would get more of an explanation as to how the two game link and while portal was never hinted to, for obvious reasons (it didn't come out for another 7 or so years, duh!), I could see how the stories linked on the simple basis of the apocolypse. I'm excited to find out the rest of the story in Half life 2!
The controls are useful and it is very nice that you can save at any point rather than just key points, this is an extremely helpful feature, especially for the ever frustrating jump climb! :P The gameplay is fun and flows pretty smoothly. I have no big problems with the run/jump style. The Story was phenomenol and I really enjoyed it! They put a lot of work and effort into building a great story line.
The Dialogue is pretty good. You never hear Gordon speak, only scientists, guards, etc. which at times is quite comical. The Level Design is also phenominal. They did a lot of work on putting out as many unique levels as possible and they did a great job. The AI is not too much of a problem and I think it was quite advanced for its time. The enemy wont shoot at you if they cant see you which is actually quite nice. They sometimes get into a more strategic formation to face me which is also good work.
The World Design, along with the level design, is phenomenol. The story is linear, but with good cause. It is a story, not an RPG choice adventure. VALVe tells the story via game and I really like it! The Graphics are absolutely lesser than now, but I love it! The nostalgia is great! I really appreciate the old game made available for current PCs because a lot of the modern games can only be supported by super computers and its really nice to be able to play a quality game on a netbook, crappy PC, etc. Finally, the sound goes along with the nostalgia and I love the 8-bit sound effects and voices and music. The music is few and far between, but that just makes it all the more appreciated.
This is definitely one of the video games you need to play. Please support this amazing company, they created Steam and many wonderful games, like Portal and Half Life. Buy this game!

The Review outline style was taken from Game Developers Tycoon. Please also consider that game for it is great! :D

reviewText: Am I really sitting here writing about why Half-Life is good? Yes, I am, but that's because it's so amazingly fantastic, so mind-blowingly good, so unquestionably a masterpiece, that it deserves to have what has already been said about it millions of times said again by me. If there was any doubt in my mind that video games are art, it has been eradicated by this game and it's sequel. This may seem like an odd choice for claiming games are art, but I believe it has the depth, complexity, and emotional attachment that a true work of art has. People latch on to games like Braid as examples of games as art because they outwardly appear to be artsy" games
date: with vague plots and symbolism and plenty of emotional torment thrown at you
recommended: but once you look deeper a certain amount of pretentiousness is revealed
hoursPlayed: and you have to question how meaningful such works really are. Half-Life is not pretentious. It is not trying to appear "artsy
voteText: because it knows it has enough value to not have to hide behind such a facade to convince the public of it's worth. It may seem silly to reccomend such a famous game because everyone's played it
helpfulPercent: but no matter how famous a game is there will always be someone who hasn't played it (I know I have a whole bucket list of essential titles that remain unplayed, such as Final Fantasy VI and Resident Evil 4), and if that person is you, rectify the situation as soon as possible. It remains a staple of any gamer's collection for a reason. Just be careful dismounting ladders. Fall damage is a ♥♥♥♥♥ in this game.\n\nScore: 10/10

reviewText: The graphics are outdated, but the gameplay still holds. The gameplay is absolutely incredible, the story is interesting, and the controls are tighter then the skinny jeans I tried to wear in 7th grade. Exciting and thrilling despite the graphical limitations. It's almost difficult to believe this was made in 1998, well if the character models didn't look like they had been modeled out of clay and then dropped multiple times. I especially love the health and suit mechanics. It may be old, but it gives you a truly epic feel. Boss fights though scarce are some of my favorites. Thrilling, epic, awesome are all words that could be used to describe this game. I thought I had seen the real experience with the Black Mesa Half-Life 2 Mod, but I was mistaken. There are some differences, and the mod doesn't have the same atmosphere as the original. The original game is easier anyway and I respect that this game is one of the best out there and highly recommend that you play it if you get a chance. It works on even low-rate computers like mine and is way underpriced if you ask me. The music is great, and the level design is some of the best that I have ever seen. Among my few minor complaints are that the friendly NPCs are terrible at following, limited voice actor variety, crouch jumping is annoying, and what you need to do is sometimes nearly impossible to figure out without lots of trial and error. All in all one of my personal favorite games. 11 snarks out of 10.

reviewText: By modern standards, this game has pretty terrible graphics. But in its time, it was revolutionary, and the depth of its storyline and gameplay still captivate players today. Those grainy graphics can still scare the pants off a gamer who, after finding a safe spot to reload, walks right into the next wave of guards, or takes a headcrab to the face. This is one of the only games that has literally made me jump out of my chair. What's not to love?

reviewText:
Few games have been as important to the video game industry as Half-Life. The first game to directly integrate storytelling into its gameplay, it revolutionized the FPS genre. The player never leaves the perspective of Gordon Freeman, a theoretical physicist who becomes an unlikely hero after finding himself in the middle of a disaster.

This game is filled with non-stop action, and it presents no cutscenes, leaving the player in full control of Gordon's actions during the whole game. Its story is one of the best stories ever told in games, and this is where it all started.

It also presents plenty of detailed environments, and you really get the feeling of exploring a top secret research facility; and all the different weapons provide a rewarding experience during fight scenes.

This game is highly recommendable. Not just that, this game MUST be played by every gamer out there. You surely won't regret it.

reviewText: The game that started it all; Half-Life. You play as Gordon Freeman, a scientist with a PhD in Theoretical Physics, who works in Black Mesa. You're running late for your experiment. Although, after this, you'll wish you were on a sick day.\n-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThis game is a masterpiece. It has an immersive, original plotline, excellently executed enemies (with their own weaknesses and strengths, mind you), epic weapons, and great graphics that even still hold up today.
